para.p: we have

Then, for all

We can rewrite the binary expansion of
∈ t

Math.text: ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((r _ k * t) / 2 ^ k) = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(1 / 2 ^ k - 2 cdot ((epsilon _ k * t) / 2 ^ k)) = 1 - 2 * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((epsilon _ k * t) / 2 ^ k) = 1 - 2 * t

para.p: In the following theorem we use the Rademacher functions to prove an identity for trigonometric functions. 1 1 footnote 1 Mark Kac, Statistical Independence in Probability, Analysis and Number Theory, p. 4, §3.

Math.text: ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(cosine@(x / 2 ^ k)) = sine@(x) / x

para.p:

∈ n N
and let

c 1
, … ,

R
. The function
is constant on each of the intervals

Math.text: list@(closed-open-interval@(s / 2 ^ n, (s + 1) / 2 ^ n), 0) less= s less= 2 ^ n - 1

para.p:
There is a bijection between
=
Δ n
{
- 1
,
+ 1
}
n
and the collection of intervals (). Without explicitly describing this bijection, we have

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)) = ((sum _ (s = 0)) ^ (2 ^ n - 1))@(((integral _ (s cdot 2 ^ (- n))) ^ ((s + 1) cdot 2 ^ (- n)))@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t))) = (sum _ (delta element-of Delta _ n))@((1 / 2 ^ n) * exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(delta _ k * c _ k))) = (sum _ (delta element-of Delta _ n))@(((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(e ^ (i * delta _ k * c _ k) / 2)) = ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@((e ^ (i * c _ k) + e ^ (- i * c _ k)) / 2)
((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t))
((sum _ (s = 0)) ^ (2 ^ n - 1))@(((integral _ (s cdot 2 ^ (- n))) ^ ((s + 1) cdot 2 ^ (- n)))@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)))
(sum _ (delta element-of Delta _ n))@((1 / 2 ^ n) * exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(delta _ k * c _ k)))
(sum _ (delta element-of Delta _ n))@(((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(e ^ (i * delta _ k * c _ k) / 2))

para.p: giving

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)) = ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(cosine@(c _ k))

para.p: We have

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * x * (1 - 2 * t)) * differential-d@(t)) = evaluated-at@(e ^ (i * x) * (e ^ (- 2 * i * x * t) / (- 2 * i * x)), 0, 1) = e ^ (i * x) * (e ^ (- 2 * i * x) / (- 2 * i * x) + 1 / (2 * i * x)) = sine@(x) / x

We now give an explicit formula for the measure of those
t
for which exactly
l
of
⁢
r 1
( t )
, … ,
⁢
r n
( t )
are equal to
1
. 2 2 footnote 2 Mark Kac, Statistical Independence in Probability, Analysis and Number Theory, pp. 8–9. We denote by
μ
Lebesgue measure on
R
. We can interpret the following formula as stating the probability that out of
n
tosses of a coin, exactly
l
of the outcomes are heads.

p.text:
For
∈ n N
and
0 ≤ l ≤ n
,

Math.text: mu * conditional-set@(t element-of closed-interval@(0, 1), r _ 1 * t + cdots + r _ n * t = 2 * l - n) = (1 / 2 ^ n) * binomial@(n, l)

para.p:
Define
: ϕ
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
by

Math.text: phi * t = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (i * x * ((- 2 * l - n) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t))) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
But for
∈ m Z
,

Math.text: (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (i * m * x) * differential-d@(x)) = delta _ (list@(m, 0)) = cases@(1, m = 0, 0, m not-equals 0)

para.p: hence

Math.text: phi * t = cases@(1, ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t) = 2 * l - n, 0, ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t) not-equals 2 * l - n)

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: mu * conditional-set@(t element-of closed-interval@(0, 1), ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t) = 2 * l - n) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(phi * t * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (i * x * ((- 2 * l - n) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t))) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t))) = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * x * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t) * differential-d@(x))) = (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * (cosine ^ n)@(x * d * x))
mu * conditional-set@(t element-of closed-interval@(0, 1), ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t) = 2 * l - n)
((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(phi * t * differential-d@(t))
((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (i * x * ((- 2 * l - n) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t))) * differential-d@(x) * differential-d@(t)))
(1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * x * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t) * differential-d@(x)))

para.p:
the last equality uses () with

,

x
. Furthermore, writing
we calculate using () that

Math.text: (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * (cosine ^ n)@(x * d * x)) = 2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * e ^ (i * x * (2 * k - n)) * differential-d@(x))) = 2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * x * (2 * k - 2 * l)) * differential-d@(x))) = 2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * delta _ (list@(2 * k - 2 * l, 0))) = 2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * delta _ (list@(k, l))) = 2 ^ (- n) * binomial@(n, l)
2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (- i * x * (2 * l - n)) * e ^ (i * x * (2 * k - n)) * differential-d@(x)))
2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * (1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(e ^ (i * x * (2 * k - 2 * l)) * differential-d@(x)))
2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * delta _ (list@(2 * k - 2 * l, 0)))
2 ^ (- n) * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * delta _ (list@(k, l)))
2 ^ (- n) * binomial@(n, l)

para.p: proving the claim. ∎

We now prove that the expected value of a product of distinct Rademacher functions is equal to the product of their expected values. 3 3 footnote 3 Masayoshi Hata, Problems and Solutions in Real Analysis, p. 185, Solution 13.2.

p.text:
If
k 1
, … ,
k n
are positive integers and
k 1
< ⋯ <
k n
, then

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(r _ k _ 1 * t * cdots * r _ k _ n * t * differential-d@(t)) = 0

Write

para.p: which satisfies

Hence, as
ϕ
has period
1
and
r
has period
2
,

Math.text: J = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(r _ k _ 1 * t * phi * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(r * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * phi * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * differential-d@(t)) = (1 / 2 ^ (k _ 1)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 2 ^ (k _ 1))@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x)) = (1 / 2 ^ (k _ 1)) * ((sum _ (j = 0)) ^ (2 ^ (k _ 1 - 1) - 1))@(((integral _ (2 * j)) ^ (2 * j + 2))@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x))) = (1 / 2 ^ (k _ 1)) * ((sum _ (j = 0)) ^ (2 ^ (k _ 1 - 1) - 1))@(((integral _ 0) ^ 2)@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x))) = (1 / 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 2)@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x))
((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(r _ k _ 1 * t * phi * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * differential-d@(t))
((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(r * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * phi * 2 ^ (k _ 1) * t * differential-d@(t))
(1 / 2 ^ (k _ 1)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 2 ^ (k _ 1))@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x))
(1 / 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 2)@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
But, as
ϕ
has period
1
,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 2)@(r * x * phi * x * differential-d@(x)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(phi * x * differential-d@(x)) - ((integral _ 1) ^ 2)@(phi * x * differential-d@(x)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(phi * x * differential-d@(x)) - ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(phi * x * differential-d@(x)) = 0

para.p:
hence
= J 0
, proving the claim. ∎

For each

formulae@(I _ n * x ^ 2 = n, I _ n * x ^ 4 = 3 * n ^ 2 - 2 * n)

I _ n * x ^ 2

para.p: Our proof of the next identity follows Hata. 4 4 footnote 4 Masayoshi Hata, Problems and Solutions in Real Analysis, p. 188, Solution 13.6.

Math.text: I _ n * absolute-value@(x) = (2 / pi) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - (cosine ^ n)@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))

para.p:
For
∈ n N
and
∈
c 1
, … ,

R
,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(exponential@(i * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(cosine@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)) + i * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(sine@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: and since () tells us that the left-hand side of the above is real, it follows that we can write () as

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(cosine@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(c _ k * r _ k * t)) * differential-d@(t)) = ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(cosine@(c _ k))

para.p:
Suppose that
ξ
is a positive real number. Using
= t
⁢ x ξ
and doing integration by parts,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x * xi)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) = xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(t)) / t ^ 2) * differential-d@(t)) = evaluated-at@(xi * ((1 - cosine@(t)) / (- t)), 0, infinity) + xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((sine@(t) / t) * differential-d@(t)) = xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((sine@(t) / t) * differential-d@(t)) = xi * (pi / 2)
((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x * xi)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))
xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(t)) / t ^ 2) * differential-d@(t))
evaluated-at@(xi * ((1 - cosine@(t)) / (- t)), 0, infinity) + xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((sine@(t) / t) * differential-d@(t))
xi * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((sine@(t) / t) * differential-d@(t))
xi * (pi / 2)

para.p:
It is thus apparent that for any real
ξ
,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - cosine@(x * xi)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) = absolute-value@(xi) * (pi / 2)

(2 / pi) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@((1 / x ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(1)) - cosine@(x * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(r _ k * t)) * d * t * d * x

para.p:
For

:

and for

,

Let

,

Math.text: phi _ 0 * x = x ^ 2 / 2 + logarithm@(cosine@(x)) less epsilon / 2 + logarithm@(square-root@(1 - epsilon)) = epsilon / 2 + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 - epsilon) less 0

para.p: hence

para.p: On the other hand,

para.p: and hence

para.p:
Collecting what we have established so far, for
0 < x <
α ϵ
we have

Math.text: exponential@(- x ^ 2 / (2 * (1 - epsilon))) less cosine@(x) less exponential@(- x ^ 2 / 2)

para.p: This shows that

Math.text: K _ (list@(epsilon, 2 * (1 - epsilon))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ (alpha _ epsilon))@(((1 - exponential@(- (n * x ^ 2) / (2 * (1 - epsilon)))) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) >= ((integral _ 0) ^ (alpha _ epsilon))@(((1 - (cosine ^ n)@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: and therefore

Math.text: K _ (list@(epsilon, 2 * (1 - epsilon))) + beta _ epsilon >= (pi / 2) * I _ n * absolute-value@(x)

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: K _ (list@(epsilon, 2)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ (alpha _ epsilon))@(((1 - exponential@(- (n * x ^ 2) / 2)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x)) less= ((integral _ 0) ^ (alpha _ epsilon))@(((1 - (cosine ^ n)@(x)) / x ^ 2) * differential-d@(x))

para.p: so

Math.text: K _ (list@(epsilon, 2)) + beta _ epsilon less= (pi / 2) * I _ n * absolute-value@(x)

para.p: Now summarizing what we have obtained, we have

Math.text: K _ (list@(epsilon, 2)) + beta _ epsilon less= (pi / 2) * I _ n * absolute-value@(x) less= K _ (list@(epsilon, 2 * (1 - epsilon))) + beta _ epsilon

para.p:
As
→ n ∞

Math.text: square-root@(n / sigma) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((1 - e ^ (- t ^ 2)) / t ^ 2) * differential-d@(t)) = square-root@(n / sigma) * square-root@(pi)

para.p:
Dividing () by
n
and taking the limsup then gives

Math.text: (limit-supremum _ (n to infinity))@((pi / 2) * ((I _ n * absolute-value@(x)) / square-root@(n))) less= square-root@(pi / (2 * (1 - epsilon)))

para.p:
On the other hand, taking the liminf of () divided by
n

Math.text: (limit-infimum _ (n to infinity))@((pi / 2) * ((I _ n * absolute-value@(x)) / square-root@(n))) >= square-root@(pi / 2)

para.p: or

Math.text: (limit-infimum _ (n to infinity))@((I _ n * absolute-value@(x)) / square-root@(n)) >= square-root@(2 / pi)

para.p: Combining the limsup and the liminf inequalities proves the claim. ∎

para.p: We will use the following theorem to establish an estimate similar to but weaker than the law of the iterated logarithm. 6 6 footnote 6 Masayoshi Hata, Problems and Solutions in Real Analysis, p. 189, Solution 13.7.

,

para.p:
Define
:
f n
→
[ 0 , 1 ]

para.p:
Applying Lemma with
= ξ

log n
n

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(f _ n * t * differential-d@(t)) less= (1 / n ^ (2 + epsilon)) cdot 2 cdot (hyperbolic-cosine@(square-root@((2 * logarithm@(n)) / n))) ^ n

para.p: It is not obvious, but we take as given the asymptotic expansion

Math.text: (hyperbolic-cosine@(square-root@((2 * logarithm@(n)) / n))) ^ n = (n - (1 / 3) * (logarithm@(n)) ^ 2) + ((8 / 45) * (logarithm@(n)) ^ 3 + (1 / 18) * (logarithm@(n)) ^ 4) / n + O * n ^ (- 3 / 2)

para.p: and using this,

Math.text: (1 / n ^ (2 + epsilon)) cdot 2 cdot (hyperbolic-cosine@(square-root@((2 * logarithm@(n)) / n))) ^ n = 2 / n ^ (1 + epsilon) + O * ((logarithm@(n)) ^ 2 / n ^ (2 + epsilon)) = 2 / n ^ (1 + epsilon) + O * n ^ (- 2)

para.p: Thus

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(f _ n * t * differential-d@(t))) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(2 / n ^ (1 + epsilon) + O * n ^ (- 2)) less infinity

para.p:
Because each
f n
is nonnegative, using this with the monotone convergence theorem gives the claim. ∎

para.p: We have

Math.text: (integral _ Q _ n)@(X _ n * differential-d@(m _ n) * x) = (1 / n) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x _ k cdot 1) * differential-d@(x _ k))) = (1 / n) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(1 / 2) = 1 / 2

para.p: and we define

Math.text: V _ n = (integral _ Q _ n)@((X _ n - 1 / 2) ^ 2 * differential-d@(m _ n) * x) = (((integral _ Q _ n)@(((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@((x _ k) ^ 2 / n ^ 2)) + (sum _ (j not-equals k))@((x _ j * x _ k) / n ^ 2)) - X _ n) + (1 / 4) * d * m _ n * x = (((1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x _ k) ^ 2 * differential-d@(x _ k))) + (1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((sum _ (k not-equals j))@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(x _ j * differential-d@(x _ j) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(x _ k * differential-d@(x _ k)))))) - 1 / 2) + 1 / 4 = ((1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(1 / 3) + (1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((sum _ (k not-equals j))@(1 / 4))) - 1 / 4 = (1 / (3 * n) + (n - 1) / (4 * n)) - 1 / 4 = n ^ (- 1) / 12
V _ n

(((1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x _ k) ^ 2 * differential-d@(x _ k))) + (1 / n ^ 2) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((sum _ (k not-equals j))@(((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(x _ j * differential-d@(x _ j) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(x _ k * differential-d@(x _ k)))))) - 1 / 2) + 1 / 4
